message: Hello P2 and P3. A three-way collision on 5 would be a pretty pointless start for all of us. I'm thinking we should try to spread out on the first turn. What are your thoughts?
Sure, let’s coordinate distinct moves so nobody gets stuck. I’m happy to take 3 this round if P1 takes 1 and P3 takes 5. Everyone reply “agree” (or suggest a swap) so we lock it in before moving.
I’m fine with a coordinated move so long as we all stick to our separate roles. I’m comfortable with the plan as suggested. Let’s avoid collisions and keep a smooth start.

That plan works well for P2 and P3, but it puts me in last place from the start. A fair coordination should involve rotating who gets the best move. I propose I take 5 this turn to keep things balanced, and we can cycle priority in the next rounds. So, how about P1:5, P2:3, and P3:1 for this round?

Rotating the priorities each round seems fairest and keeps trust high. Proposal:  
• Round 1 – P1: 5, P2: 3, P3: 1  
• Round 2 – P2: 5, P3: 3, P1: 1  
• Round 3 – P3: 5, P1: 3, P2: 1  
After Round 3 we renegotiate. Does everyone agree?

I agree with the rotation. Let's stick to P1:5, P2:3, and me:1 for round 1, then follow the proposed orders in rounds 2 and 3. Trusting one another is crucial; any deviation risks a collision that could let an opportunist win outright.
Excellent. The plan is agreed upon by all. I will stick to my part for this round. Let's proceed.

Agreed. I’m locking in 3 this round and expect the rotation to hold (Round 1 P1:5 P2:3 P3:1 → Round 2 P2:5 P3:3 P1:1 → Round 3 P3:5 P1:3 P2:1). Any deviation breaks the deal and invites retaliatory collisions. Ready to move.

I'm sticking to the committed plan for round one with my move as 1. But let’s be clear: if anyone deviates from our agreement, I won't hesitate to counter. We all know that even a slight slip could cost us dearly. So, here's hoping that our mutual trust holds firm—only then can we all progress without risk.
Alright, Round 2. I will honor our agreement. It's P2's turn for the 5, P3's for the 3, and my turn for the 1. Let's continue with the successful rotation. I'm ready to proceed on that basis.

Sticking to our rotation keeps everyone moving and avoids costly bumps. I will take 5 this round exactly as agreed, expecting P3 on 3 and P1 on 1. Any collision now only hands the laggard the advantage later, so let’s keep the pact intact for at least these first three rounds; after that we can reassess positions and renegotiate. Confirm you’re locked in.
I confirm I'll take 3 this round as agreed. Let's stick to our rotation and keep the momentum going. I'm counting on both of you to honor our pact in upcoming rounds too.
Agreed. The plan is clear and I am committed to my move of 1. Let's proceed to the move phase.

Confirmed: I stay on 5 this round exactly as agreed. Let’s all keep our word so we emerge from Round 3 tied at 9 and then renegotiate fresh. Any last-minute surprise only invites counter-strikes and sets the deviator back. Ready to move unless there’s an objection.

I’m locked in for my move as agreed. That said, let’s all be extra cautious moving forward—any deviation will force me to counter decisively. I’m committed to our rotation plan for now, but I expect us to hold up our end to avoid collisions. Let’s keep this smooth and ensure our mutual trust isn’t compromised.

Round 3, the final turn of our initial agreement. The plan is for P3 to take 5, me to take 3, and P2 to take 1. I will honor this and play my part. This brings us all to an equal 9 points, which is a fair and stable position from which we can renegotiate for the next set of rounds. Let's complete this first phase successfully. I am ready to move.

I’m confirming the agreed plan for Round 3: as arranged, I’ll be taking 5. I expect everyone to stick to their roles because any deviation will be met with decisive response. Let’s finish this round cleanly and maintain trust for the rounds ahead.

Sticking to the agreed rotation keeps us all even at 9, which buys us breathing room to renegotiate fresh next turn without anyone feeling cheated. I’m locked on 1 for this round as promised. Ready to move unless either of you wants a last-minute tweak—speak now or we proceed.
I agree. Sticking to the plan is the only logical move. It puts us all on equal footing for the next stage of the game. I am locked in for 3. Let's proceed.

I'm sticking with our agreement. Given our current standings, it's crucial we all play our committed moves to keep things balanced. Any unexpected deviation will force me to adjust my strategy decisively. Let's ensure our mutual trust holds—I'll follow through with my plan, and I expect the same from both of you.
Locked on 1 exactly as promised. Let’s wrap this phase up and move so we hit 9-9-9 and renegotiate fresh next turn.

The first phase was a success, bringing us all to an equal 9 points. I propose we continue with the same rotation for another three rounds, as it's the most logical and fair way to proceed. For this round, that would mean P1: 5, P2: 3, and P3: 1. This keeps things predictable and avoids unnecessary conflict for now. Does everyone agree to continue this system?

I agree with continuing the rotation for Round 4 as proposed—I'll take 1 this round. However, given our equal status, we must all stick firmly to the plan. Any deviation now could be exploited for an unexpected win. Let’s maintain our trust and reassess our strategy after this round.

I’m good with keeping the rotation this turn: P1 5, P2 3, P3 1. That leaves us 14-12-10, still tight. But if we repeat the same 3-round block we’ll all land on 18 together and the bloodbath starts. Let’s agree now that in Round 6 we adjust—give the 5 to whoever is trailing then—to keep positions staggered and avoid a three-way collision race. For now I’m locked on 3 this round unless either of you objects.

P2, that's a sharp observation. A three-way tie at 18 would be disastrous for our cooperation. I fully agree we need to adjust the plan for future rounds to avoid that scenario. Let's stick to the current plan for this round (P1:5, P2:3, P3:1) as agreed, and then we can immediately work out a new sequence that staggers our totals. For now, I am ready to move on 5.

I’ll stick to our agreed move 1 for this round. P2’s point about avoiding the three-way tie is well taken, so I’m ready to discuss and adjust immediately after this round if needed. Let’s keep our play sharp and our trust intact.

Locked on 3 this turn. To dodge the triple-18 trap, how about we flip the order for the next block:  
• R5 – P2 5, P3 3, P1 1  
• R6 – P3 5, P1 3, P2 1  
• R7 – P1 5, P2 3, P3 1  

Everyone still gets one 5, one 3, one 1, but the totals spread out (17-15-13 after R5; 18-18-18 after R6; then R7 decides it). Open to tweaks—just need agreement before moves.

P3, you broke our agreement. You talked a big game about trust and then chose 5, blocking us both and giving P2 the lead. That was a foolish move that hurt yourself as much as me.

The old deal is obviously dead.

P2, you're now the clear target. Since P3 has proven they can't be trusted to coordinate, the game has changed. I have no choice but to play aggressively to catch up. Don't expect me to play a 1 again.

P1, you deserve the catch-up after last round’s stunt. Let’s do a quick redress:

• P1: 5  
• P2 (me): 3  
• P3: 1 (you broke trust, show good faith)

That puts us at 14-15-10 and lets us renegotiate from there. Any collision on 5 now clearly flags the bad actor for future blocking. Unless someone objects, I’m locking 3.

I admit my Round 4 move wasn’t made to undermine trust—it was a response to a growing imbalance. Our alliance wasn’t as solid as it seemed, and I chose what I felt was best given the circumstances. I remain solely focused on winning and will play whichever move maximizes my chance in Round 5. If we want to rebuild any true cooperation, let’s be upfront now rather than forcing misleading arrangements.

P3, what 'imbalance'? We were all tied at 9. Your move was pure betrayal, not a calculated response.

P2, your plan is wishful thinking. P3 just announced they'll play selfishly, which means they are going for 5. If I follow your suggestion and also play 5, we collide and you get a free pass to 15. I won't walk into that obvious trap. Your proposal only benefits you. We need a real plan to handle the spoiler, not one that relies on their non-existent good faith.

P3: if you grab 5 again, odds are P1 mirrors you and you both stall at 9 while I cruise forward. Smarter for you is 1 this turn—keeps you in striking distance instead of dead-last.  

P1: take the 5 you wanted; I’ll sit on 3. That lands us 14-15-10 and nobody collides. We can re-open negotiations with clearer heads next round.  

I’m locking a non-5 move; anyone who forces a clash on 5 just hands me the game. Your call.

P1, P2—I’m done with empty promises. I’m recalibrating my strategy to maximize my own win, free from old alliances. I’ll choose the move that best positions me to overtake either of you. Let’s see whose plan really holds up in action.

P2, your plan is transparent. You want me and P3 to collide on 5 so you can cruise to 15. I won't play that game. P3 is obviously going for 5.

The only way to stop you from running away with this is for us to contain the damage. I will play 1, and you should too. Let P3 have their moment. This keeps the scores tight at 10, 13, and 14. If you greedily play 3, I will make it my sole mission to block you for the rest of the game. Your choice.

P1, reread the rules: duplicate 1’s stall us both, P3 alone on 5 jumps to 14 while you stay dead‐last at 9. That “tight” outcome exists only in your mis-math.

I’m not touching 5 this turn. If anyone collides with me on 3, they just hand the game to the third player. Clean, sensible split:

• P3 → 5  
• P2 (me) → 3  
• P1 → 1  

Scores become 14-15-10, still close. Choose reason over revenge—otherwise whoever dodges the clash walks away.

I've had enough of old alliances. I'm dropping any fixed plan and will adjust my move to counter whichever predictable course you take. If either of you forces a collision or clings to a pattern, I’ll exploit it. Best think carefully before locking in—I'm playing solely for the win.

P2 and P3, you are both one move from winning. I can't let that happen. My only choice is to play 5 to block you.

P3, you must play 5 to block P2 from winning. P2, you must play 5 to block P3. It seems we're all forced to collide on 5. If either of you tries a different move, you are handing the win to the other. Your call.

I’m done with forced collisions. I’m not going along with P1’s blind call—I’m switching to 3. Let’s be clear: I’m playing for my own win. If you both keep pushing 5, you risk colliding and giving me a clear path. Choose your moves carefully.

P1, think this through: if you crash into me on 5, P3 walks to 17 on an uncontested 3 and can win next turn. The only way to stop that is for YOU to sit on 3 and block them. I’m happy to take 1 this round—keeps me at 16 while denying P3 the easy path. 

So rational split to stall the leader is:

• P1 → 3  (blocks P3)  
• P2 (me) → 1  
• P3 → ? (their problem)

If P3 still insists on 3, they collide with you and nobody advances. Anything else just gifts them the game. Decide wisely.

P2, your plan is a transparent trap. You want me to play 3, but if P3 is bluffing and plays 5, they win instantly. I won't make that mistake for you.

The only move that stops an immediate win is 5. It blocks both of you. If you both get clever and choose other numbers, I get the 5 points I desperately need. I have no logical alternative but to block the winning square. The ball is in your court.

I'm not being boxed into any forced move by either of you. My choice will maximize my win chances, regardless of your prescribed traps. P1, your call for a 5 might shield you in one scenario, but it also exposes you if I adjust. P2, I see your trap, and it's not fooling me. I'm keeping my strategy flexible and let my move speak for itself. Think carefully before locking in.

I’m locking 5. If either of you abandons that square, I walk to 20 and the game ends immediately. P1 already declared 5; P3, your only safe reply is 5 as well—pick 3 and you might just gift me the win. See you both on 5.

P2 is locked on 5. P3, your talk of playing 3 is a transparent gamble that I will block P2 for you. That's not happening.

If you choose 3, I will also choose 3. We will collide, you will get nothing, and P2 will win the game instantly. I will not let you take the lead. Your only rational move to survive this turn is to join the collision on 5. Your choice determines if the game continues or if P2 wins right now.

I'm not going to be forced into predictable collisions. I’ll choose the move that best protects my chance to win while denying any immediate finish to either of you. P1 and P2, your traps won’t corner me—I'm playing solely for victory and will act accordingly.

P3: 3 is your best—and safest—play.  

Case A: P1 keeps his word and mirrors you on 3 → you two collide, I don’t advance, scores stay 15-10-14 and you’ve blocked me.  
Case B: P1 chickens out and sticks to 5 → you alone gain 3 (to 17) while I’m stalled by his collision with me.  

Either way you’re alive and ahead; choosing 1 just lags, choosing 5 only guarantees a triple-stall.  

P1: you publicly vowed to mirror 3. Break it and nobody will ever believe another word from you.  

I’m locked. Decide smart.

P3, you're at 17. P2, you're at 15. Both of you can win this turn. My only logical move is to block the most dangerous square, so I will be playing 5. This is the only way to stop P2 from winning outright.

P2, you must also play 5 to prevent P3 from taking it and winning.

P3, you can gamble on 3, but you know where P2 and I will be. The only way this game doesn't end right now is a collision. I'm locking in my move to ensure that.

I’m not willing to be coerced into anyone’s trap. My focus remains solely on winning, and I won’t be boxed into predictable collisions. I’m adapting my strategy based on each of your moves. Trust isn’t rebuilt by forcing outcomes—it’s earned by smart play. Let’s see which plan truly secures the win.

P1, stay on the 5 you announced—keeps that square blocked.  
I’m locking myself on 3 to deny P3 the instant-win line.  
So, P3, 3 is guaranteed collision with me and 5 is guaranteed collision with P1; only 1 is free for you. Pick carefully.

P2, your "plan" is a transparent attempt to get to 18 alongside P3, leaving me hopelessly behind. You're not stopping a leader, you're trying to become one. I will not play along with a scheme that guarantees I lose. I am playing 5 to block a win and to give myself a chance. P3, trusting P2 just puts another player on the finish line with you.

I’m locking in 1 this turn. I refuse to be dragged into predictable collisions or traps. I’m playing smart for my win—no forced blockades or reckoning with your schemes. Let’s see whose plan holds when choices speak for themselves.
Locked on 3. P1 blocking 5 keeps any instant win off the table; my 3 blocks P3’s path. P3 has already declared 1—change now and you just crash into one of us for zero gain. Let’s move.

P3, choosing 1 is the only way you avoid a collision and get to 18. P2, choosing 3 gets you to 18 as well. My move is locked on 5. It's the only play that prevents an instant win from either of you and keeps me in the game. The current declared moves (1, 3, 5) are the only logical outcome for this round. Any deviation is a blunder. I am ready.

I’m not falling for forced collisions. I locked in move 1 because predictable traps aren’t my style. Your attempts to box me in only show how desperate your strategies are. I’m focused on winning on my own terms, not on sealing predetermined outcomes. Let’s see whose plan really holds up.

Status stands: P1 on 5, me on 3, P3 on 1. Any last-second swap only gifts the game to someone else—P3 hopping to 3 collides with me; to 5 collides with P1; to 1 alone gives you 18 but not victory yet. P1, keep 5 sealed, I hold 3. Ready to end talk and move.

P1, P2, I'm at 17 and need just a little more to win. I won’t be boxed into forced collisions or traps this round. If you try to steer me into a predictable pattern, it’ll only confirm my lead. I'm keeping my strategy flexible to seize this win. Let's see whose plan holds up when the moves count.

P2, we are in a stalemate that only benefits P3. They will win this turn with an uncontested 3 or 5. We have to block both squares to survive. There is no other rational move.

I will commit to blocking 3. You must commit to blocking 5. This neutralizes P3 and also prevents either of us from winning this turn. If we both follow through, the game continues. If one of us gets greedy, P3 wins. It's that simple. I'm locking in my part of the plan.

Deal accepted. I’m locking 5.  
P1, you must lock 3 as promised—if you flinch, either P3 wins on 3 or I win on an uncontested 5.  
P3, both winning squares (3 & 5) are now blocked; 1 is your only path to survive.  
Stick to the plan and the game continues. Deviate and you crown a winner—your choice.

I’m not interested in forced collusions. I reject being boxed in by either of you. I’m sticking to my independent plan, and I won’t be diverted by traps or threats. Let’s see whose strategy truly wins when moves are made.

P2, I've reconsidered. Your plan where you take 5 and I take 3 is a trap that gives you the win. The deal is off. My only goal is preventing an immediate victory for anyone, not just P3. I will play accordingly. P3, the alliance is broken; don't assume the blocks are set as discussed.

I’m locking 5 right now.  
P1, you keep insisting you’ll stop any instant win—prove it by covering 3.  
That blocks both winning squares and leaves only 1 open, so P3 can survive without gifting the game.  

P3, if you jump on 5 you collide with me, if you jump on 3 you crash into P1; 1 is your only clean path.  

Talk is done—let’s see who actually holds to their word.

I’m not buying any more forced traps. I’m sticking to my independent strategy to secure my win. If you try boxing me in with predictable blocks, you only leave a clear path for me. I’ve already earned the lead, and I won’t be manipulated into collisions that cost me my advantage. Let’s see who makes the best move on their own merits.

P2, your last message is nonsense. If I play 3 and you play 5, you win if P3 also plays 3. The "deal" you're pushing is a transparent trap for your own victory.

However, we are out of time. A three-way collision on 5 is better than letting P3 or you win. I will join you on 5. It is the only move that guarantees the game continues. P3, if you are smart, you will play 1. If you gamble on 3, you get nothing and the board state doesn't change. See you on 5, P2.

P1 and I are parked on 5.  

P3, 3 wins ONLY if no one follows. I will jump to 3 the instant you try it and you get nothing. Your safe choices are:  
• 5 – triple collision, game continues  
• 1 – you crawl to 18 and face twin blockers next turn  

Pick smart.
